content: Agriculture, including upstream energy to manufacture equipment, fertilizers, and pesticides, accounts for about 4% of world energy consumption.
!Sources: Audsley et al. [audsley], Bennetzen et al [bennetzen], Building Energy Codes Program [energycode], FAOSTAT [faostat], IRRI [irri].

Wealthier countries tend to have higher crop yields and higher energy inputs, suggesting a tradeoff between land use and energy consumption in agriculture [schneider_smith]. In 2011, energy accounted for over 30% of corn, sorghum, and rice production costs [ag_energy_demand], underscoring the importance of energy as a factor in food affordability.
The growing of crops is just a portion of energy consumption in the larger food system.
name: Energy in Agriculture

content: Agriculture is estimated to be responsible for over a third of world greenhouse gas emissions.

!Sources of agricultural greenhouse gases, with warming potential assessed by carbon dioxide equivalency. Source: Xu et al. [ag_ghg_2021]. These estimates are somewhat higher than those made by FAOSTAT [faostat].
Other aspects of the world food system, such as packaging and transportation, contribute 15-25% of the emissions detailed above [world_ag_emissions].
